Unexpectedly (to me anyway), the Credentials screen popped up and I clicked Allow. Then, over 100 Emails from my Gmail account loaded. Checked Saved Logins and Oauth entry was present. Restarted Thunderbird with Troubleshoot off. Clicked Allow on the credentials screen. POP server timed out evidently because Gmail was not talking back.

Turned Troubleshoot Mode back on and restarted. I didn't see any Credentials screen, so I clicked the Get Massages 'cloud'. A message popped up at the bottom of the Thunderbird screen saying 'No New Messages'.

Thanks again for feedback.

creator: larrygad

content:
larrygad said
I don't receive any error messages. I see the same screen as Ashley posted. But, clicking Allow does not result in any activity from Gmail to Thunderbird.

How about posting your screen instead of insisting it is the same as something else!

If you mean this

The URL will not be the same. But regardless of attemts to get to the bottom of exactly what screens you see, the issue is most likely your antivirus product or it's software firewall or even your VPN. All of those things cause issues for Gmail users. Especially the VPN part these days. VPN's are rarely set up with email and anti hacking safe guards such as Google use in mind.

The authentication flow for oauth is susceptible to locally installed web servers and development environments and antivirus products that think the localhost is theirs to block. Once about 20 or 30 years ago malware used localhost to send mail as an SMTP server. SOme products are still carrying on as if spam was still an issue from malware. It is not. Ransomware, hacking and stollen identities is the items of risk today, not some 30 years old malware sending penis enlergement emails that get blocked at point of receipt because the sender fails reverse DNS lookups, DMARK, DKM,SPF etc.

You are asking folks that have no issues to help you figure out what is unique about your setup, without actually saying what your setup is.

larrygad said
Checked Config preferences: 'network.http.windows-sso.enabled' set to false. Should it be true?

What does it even do? I will google it. According to https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/windows-sso something irrelevant to Thunderbird.

larrygad said
Last night I sent a note to Google Workspace Support about this problem. No reply back received this morning. Started Thunderbird, clicked Allow, and POP server timed out as described above.

The completion of the oAuth authentication flow and the pop server timing out are only vaguely related. If you have no oAuth token it will time out after about 5 minutes because Thunderbird can not respond to the request for the token. But timeout can occur for many other reasons, including having the port blocked by a firewall.

Restarted Thunderbird in Troubleshoot Mode as suggested in another Oauth discussion thread to check Config Settings as noted there. Unexpectedly (to me anyway), the Credentials screen popped up and I clicked Allow. Then, over 100 Emails from my Gmail account loaded. Checked Saved Logins and Oauth entry was present. (A couple days ago when I found the Troubleshoot info, no Emails downloaded.) Restarted Thunderbird with Troubleshoot off. Clicked Allow on the credentials screen. POP server timed out evidently because Gmail was not talking back.

And we are back to interference for an addon, or more likely some code injected by your antivirus program. Because there should be no request for further authentication when you return from troubleshooting mode. Do you have an exception in your antivirus program for Thunderbird profile folder. It sounds to me like something is blocking the saving of the password file when the program exists. Something I have come to expect from these antivirus products that think every file write has to have their permission.

Turned Troubleshoot Mode back on and restarted. I didn't see any Credentials screen, so I clicked the Get Massages 'cloud'. A message popped up at the bottom of the Thunderbird screen saying 'No New Messages'. Thanks again for feedback.

Yep, so it works in troubleshooting mode. I have no idea what your expectations are, but having completed the authentication flow you will have an oAuth token in the password manager and unless you have a VPN or something else that triggers Google you may not be asked for any sort of credential of a very long time. It is over 12 months since I authorized anything. Google related in Thunderbird.

I would suggest you start by reviewing the addons installed in the Thunderbird addon manager. Try disabling them all next time you start Thunderbird in troubleshooting mode and restarting and see if it still works. If it does the path to determine what is the issue is simply to eliminate which is causing the issue by enabling them one at a time until it stops working again.

That does not exclude injected code from the antivirus. They make grand claims sometimes about scam and spam management. This is often done by injecting an addon into the running Thunderbird instance. Just as malware does really, ignoring Thunderbirds interfaces and permissions. Troubleshooting mode disables the addon interface so the antivirus is the next thing to turn off if it is not an addon.

creator: @next

content:
Opening an email does not do anything other than open the email. If a scam email has an attachment, never open it - do not be curious. If email contains any links do not click on them. You can always check a link by hovering over it and the real link is shown in the bottom Status Bar. Thunderbird by default does not allow any 'remote content', so it will not link to anything unless you disable the block on remote content. Emails are safe providing you do not allow remote content and do not open attachments and links.

How to attach an email as either .eml or text file to your own email.

You can 'attach' the email as a .eml to your own email that you are sending. Open a new Write message and enter info etc. Then left click on spam email and hold down to grab and drag over to the 'Write' compose window and it will get added as an attachment when you release the mouse.

Alternatively - if they do not like .eml attachments, right click on spam email and select 'Save as' and then for 'Save as type' choose 'Text files (-.txt, *.text)' Select to save to easy location such as desktop. Then you can use the same method of drag and drop into Write compose email to add as an attachment.

content:
You can simply drag selected emails out of the Trash and drop them in the Inbox.

Or you can use the right clic kmenu... Select first email in Trash Hold down Shift and click on last email and all in between get highlighted OR select first email and then use the keyboard 'Shift+A' which selects all emails in Trash Then right click on highlighted emails and choose 'Move to' and hover over the account name to see folders and click on 'Inbox'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Why the emails have suddenly been deleted and moved to TRash ?

Have you by any chance used another device to access mail such as a laptop or phone or directly logged on to the webmail account via a browser ?

IF yes: If you are using an IMAP account in Thunderbird then it can only display whatever is on server. That means if you eg: used a phone to delete a load of emails OR logged onto the webmail account and deleted a load of emails, they would get put in server TRash folder.

Start Thunderbird and the imap account will show whatever is on server, so emails are now in the Trash.

content:
Do you get any error message when you try to 'Get Messages' ? If yes, please either post an imgae of error or type error word for word verbatim.

Do you use ESET Anti-Virus ? If no: Please tell us what Anti-virus you use.

If yes: ESET AntiVirus has been known to cause issues with downloading emails.

  • https://support.eset.com/en/kb7728-unable-to-access-or-receive-emails-in-thunderbird-with-eset-product-installed

Temporarily Disable ESET SSL/TLS Filtering:

  • Open ESET's main program window.
  • Press the F5 key to access Advanced setup.
  • Click "Protections" and then expand "SSL/TLS".
  • Disable SSL/TLS filtering temporarily.
  • Re-enable it after Thunderbird is working properly and restart your computer.

Exclude Thunderbird from SSL Filtering:

  • Open ESET's main program window.
  • Go to "Advanced setup".
  • Expand "Web and Mail" and then "Web and E-mail Protections".
  • Click "Exceptions".
  • Add an exception for Thunderbird's executable file.
  • Click "OK".

creator: geoffpeters

content:
geoffpeters said
OK, I was hoping to just never see them but I guess that is not possible. Thanks.

The server receives emails because that's it's job, it would be a problem if it did not. Thunderbird access server and if you use a Pop account it will download whatever is in server Inbox to Pop account. If you use an Imap account, all imap folders can only display whatever is on server.

You could try setting up something in Webmail account which filters all @gmail.com email addresses to Trash automatically. See info:

  • https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/spam-filters-and-email-blocking-new-experience

If you use a Pop account then you would not see them in Thunderbird, but if using Imap then obviously when Trash synchronises with server you will see them. However, Comcast uses Xfinity server which I believe auto removes emails from the Trash after 14 days. So a Pop account would never see those emails and you can sure they will get auto removed off the server after 14 days.

Alternative in Thunderbird: If all the incoming emails are incoming to the Inbox then you can create a Message Filter to put emails with a Gmail address in Trash. (I understand you have already tried that option) But, obviously if a contact you know then chooses to use a Gmail address you may need to rethink that strategy.

content:
D. Abel said
How can I actually file a bug report about this?

You have not even established the existence of a bug. You have established you have things happening that you neither desire nor recognize as correct behavior but you do not have a bug.

Have you managed to get your system to loose the plot getting mails if you run in safe mode as suggested by Wayne? Personally I think you have an issue that is not related to Thunderbird except by accident as your antivirus email scanner is dead in the water. Possibly even caused by the self signed certificate it uses to hack your mail. But we have nothing either of is to support that view or any other. So reporting a bug is premature.

Try safe mode and report your results. Also try changing the check for new email to 15 minutes of more. Some providers consider it a violation of their terms of service to check more frequently. It is also possible to simply run out of free logins with frequent polling, especially as Apple mail products historically are prone to consuming all available connections (it make their product look faster if is signs in 10 times and gets 10 emails at a time). It does however make everything else stop. So turning off your phone/ laptop/tablet (other devices) as a test is also a regular part of any diagnostic process.

Access the error console (alt+ctrl+J) Clear it using the trash icon on it's toolbar Attempt to get mail. What messages appear in the console from you pressing the button?

Further logging is also possible and will be requested before anyone even looks at a bug report so get it over with early. Please report your results with each item so the process can move to the reporting of a bug or resolution.

content:
re :I've recently been forced off POP into IMAP using OAUTH by google which now requires IMAP only with Google workspace emails.

I'm not so sure that's correct. This is the official notice from Google. Starting May 1, 2025, Google Workspace accounts no longer support less secure apps, third-party apps, or devices that ask you to sign in to your Google Account with your username and password. You must use OAuth to let these apps and devices access your account.

In Thunderbird, Pop accounts can also be set up to use Authentication Method: Oauth2. It's a very simple modification and Thunderbird set this up some time ago.

You may need to disable any program using localhost eg: Apache Xampp until all is set up. 1. Edit incoming and outgoing smtp 'Authentication Method' to use 'Oauth2' 2. In Thunderbird set up to allow cookies (Settings > Privacy & Security) 3. Remove the currently stored passwords in Thunderbird 4. REstart Thunderbird, enter normal password at prompt and then select to 'Allow' Thunderbird access to server.

Oauth2 token is stored in Thunderbird and will be used from then forth.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re : I will say that I miss POP because it allowed me to "catch" all my email in the gmail server, while using it as I saw fit on my TB/local computer. Now I'm required to mirror both - which is not helpful to me.

My previous comment was posted because it sounds like you really would prefer to use POP. I forget to say - do make sure you have enabled the POP option in the webmail account > SEttings > see all settings > Forwarding Pop/IMAP

Do you still have the Pop gmail account in your Account SEttings ? If you removed it, do you know that Thunderbird does not auto delete it from the Profile ? That means if you did remove it from Account SEttings, then you can create a new pop account using correct settings and then simply alter the 'Account SEttings' > 'Server Settings' > 'Local directory:' to point to the original pop folders and all your emails.

IMAP is designed to only display whatever is on the server as seen when you logon to webmail account. So, each folder synchronises with the server everytime you access the folder and move an email. If you choose to 'move' an email out of an imap folder then it also means you are 'moving' emails off the server. If something goes wrong then you stand a good chance of losing emails.

Many people have an Anti-Virus and that AV will scan incoming files /emails and it will also scan any file that gets opened. When the AV is doing this Thunderbird temporarilly has no access to a file. I would advise that you do not want any AV scanning your profile folders or their contents. Access AV and set up an exception to not scan your Thunderbird profile folder.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Just for good measure I'm going to post the full information on what checks to make on computer, in Thunderbird etc to set up to use Oauth for a POP gmail account.

If you use POP then make sure this set up in webmail account. In gmail webmail account - Settings > See all settings > Forwarding POP/IMAP tab make sure have enabled the POP option

Firewall: Access Firewall which may be controlled by the OS or by an Anti-Virus program you installed. Thunderbird must be set up as an allowed program.

VPN Please check computer and Anti-Virus product to see if a VPN has been enabled. Server does not like VPN, it will block access. So switch off VPN or create a split tunnelling and set up Thunderbird to use it.

'Localhost' If you use a program that uses 'localhost' - some people manage websites so might use something like Apache Xampp - Switch it off until Oauth has been set up.

In Thunderbird

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • WEb Content
  • Select : 'Accept cookies from sites'
  • Accept third party cookies 'Always'
  • Click on 'Exceptions' button
  • Set up: https://accounts.google.com as 'Allow'
  • Click on 'Save Changes'

Scroll down to Passwords

  • Click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • Remove any line that mentions username = gmail email address you are trying to reset.
  • Click on 'Close'

Check you are using correct gmail settings: Account Settings select 'Server SEttings' for the account POP:

  • Server name: pop.gmail.com
  • Port: 995
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Oauth2
  • Username : full gmail email address

SMTP:

  • Description: enter the same email address as shown in username (this helps you check you are using correct smtp when you have several gmail accounts)
  • Server name: smtp.gmail.com
  • Port: 465
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Oauth2
  • Username : full gmail email address


EXit Thunderbird Wait a few moments for background files to update. Start Thunderbird

At prompt enter normal Password, then click on the 'Accept' to allow Thunderbird access to server.

IF you previously had a POP account and it's data is still stored in the profile.

  • In Account Settings
  • Select 'Server Settings' for the pop gmail account
  • Look bottom right for 'Local directory:'

It is currently pointing to a new pop gmail account.

  • click on 'Browse' button

It opens in a new window showing you contents of the current pop account which probably has a number appended to the name.

  • Go up the directory to the 'Mail' folder and select the original pop gmail account folder.
  • Click on 'Select Folder'

This will now force your new Pop account to use the original Pop account, so can see all your folders and emails.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
I really appreciate the prompt and thoughtful reply.

You are correct that I can still use POP with my gmail and through Thunderbird.

I found that I had to start a new profile and authorize the account. My struggles arose from the fact that my older POP account could not simply be changed to OAUTH, and that all the gmail literature about the new changes refers only to IMAP in a way that implies its the only way.

Thank you for steering me back on course. I found the setup process through Thunderbird was perfectly easy and got me into the new account I needed.
creator: farmerben

content:
We had a problem with Norton 360 AV and Thunderbird on 1 computer with an AOL account set to POP where Norton scanned and maybe quarantined an email causing the inbox to get messed up and the messages from that email that caused the problem and newer had parts of the email, maybe the subject and sender mixed up between them.

We solved the problem by adding an exception so the Thunderbird profiles are not scanned as suggested above and then set up our backup program Retrospect with a script to duplicate the TB profile to another folder and then run a custom scan with Norton. They say that Thunderbird cannot execute a macro like Outlook and really does not need to be virus checked but our method lets us scan occasionally without risking Thunderbirds emails if AV misinterprets something and quarantines something. Norton AV has never found a virus in the few years we have been doing this since the corruption so they are correct that you don't really need to scan but since we have the tools it gives a little peace of mind.
creator: MikeZZ

content:
MikeZZ said
We had a problem with Norton 360 AV and Thunderbird on 1 computer with an AOL account set to POP where Norton scanned and maybe quarantined an email causing the inbox to get messed up and the messages from that email that caused the problem and newer had parts of the email, maybe the subject and sender mixed up between them. We solved the problem by adding an exception so the Thunderbird profiles are not scanned as suggested above and then set up our backup program Retrospect with a script to duplicate the TB profile to another folder and then run a custom scan with Norton. They say that Thunderbird cannot execute a macro like Outlook and really does not need to be virus checked but our method lets us scan occasionally without risking Thunderbirds emails if AV misinterprets something and quarantines something. Norton AV has never found a virus in the few years we have been doing this since the corruption so they are correct that you don't really need to scan but since we have the tools it gives a little peace of mind.

The problem is this - emails are stored in mbox text files that have same name as the folder you see in Folder Pane. That means one single mbox text file document might contain hundreds of emails, each one appended to the file as they were written to it. Anti-Virus has no concept of this. They see it as one file and if anything in the file is a problem, it can try to fix or quarrantine or even completely empty all the contents. But the end result is the file gets corrupted or killed and you lose some or all emails in that file.

Any email you think is dodgy - if you delete it and then compact the folder, all traces of that email are gone so there is no need to scan anything.

Scanning an mbox file is pointless as you have no idea whether the AV is picking up on a previously deleted email and traces still exist due to a lack of compacting OR if a dodgy email then you still do not which email.

If you do allow scanning - you must also set up to get AV to tell you there is a problem, but not auto fix - it must ask you what to do. In which case, you make a note of the file and you say do not do anything.

Sometimes the AV is picking up an email already deleted, but traces still exist because the folder has not been compacted. So, first action is to compact the folders especially the Inbox and the Junk/Spam folder.

If you really need to check further, then this is a procedure I use which identifies a specific email. However, I must admit in all the decades I've used Thunderbird - compacting Inbox and Junk has always proved to be the best method of cleaning up rubbish. But the following can help to identify a problem.

  • Create a folder on desktop called 'TB-Check'
  • In Thunderbird - select folder eg: Inbox
  • click on first email and then use 'Ctrl+A' to highlight all emails in folder
  • Right click on highlighted emails and choose 'Save as'
  • In pop up window - select 'Desktop' to see list of folders it contains and then select 'TB-Check' so name appears in the bottom 'Folder: text area'
  • click on 'Select folder' button
  • All highlighted emails in the folder will get exported as single .eml files into the 'TB-Check' folder.
  • Scan that 'TB-check' folder and see if he AV picks up on any file.

The difference is this - the *.eml files are individual emails, so now you have perfect control. Any particular email deemed as a no-go... Now you can go back into Thunderbird, locate that specific email in Inbox, delete it and then compact the Inbox to ensure all traces are gone. Finally go back to the 'TB-check' folder and delete the contents then empty the computer recycle bin to ensure all traces are gone or delete the bad eml file and then you have the choice to move all other .eml fles to a backup folder if required.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: inbox shows I have 7 messages, I used to have over 2000.....where did the rest of them go??
creator: artandframing123

content:
You didn't tell what happened before your messages "disappeared". First: do you use a POP or an IMAP account? When you use IMAP your messages are stored on the server of your email provider which has nothing to do with Thunderbird or Mozilla. With the IMAP protocol Thunderbird (or any other email client) reflects the situation on the sever like in a mirror, that means Thunderbird synchronises with the server.

With the POP protocol messages are stored locally on Thunderbird. When you download messages from the server Inbox they will be stored in your Thunderbird profile. According to your server settings in Thunderbird downloaded messages grosso modo may stay on the server or may be deleted from the sever immediately or after some time.

The fact that your Inbox shows only 7 messages may be caused by an erroneous choice of message view. That's why I asked you whether you have activated the Quick Filter and now want to explain its use by an exemple: in my image I show an account Inbox which contains 122 messages. Now I activate the Quick Filter button "Show only unread messages" and the thread pane displays only 3 messages, because these are the unread messages of a total of 122 messages in Inbox.

I would like that you show a similar screen shot, so we can see whether you are a victim of this frequent "view" choice error.
creator: Mapenzi

I use a POP account None of the quick filter buttons are activated

content: I back up the computer every week. Instead of going back to the time before this happened, is there any way to look at the files of the back up to maybe pull out the inbox from there? I don't want to restore an entire backup because I have a lot of work I did in between

content: If the inbox folder was compacted, where does all the info go? What is the process of compacting a folder?
creator: artandframing123

content:
Compact removes deleted messages from folder files. If antivirus conflicts with the compact process, it is possible to lose the entire file - it would be very unusual to lose individual messages and be left with a usable folder..

Regardless, I think you are well past the point where any compact related files are left from the period where the inbox went bad.

Just get from your backup the Inbox file that has the most messages, put a renamed copy of that in the "Local Folders" directory, then copy the message out of that renamed folder.
